Columbus.Action: Encourages soldiers to marry native women.
Promised a paradise but created a hell full of horrors.
Lies delirious in fever, makes no effort to swat insects crawling on his face.
Encourages soldiers to marry native women and promises a paradise but instead creates a hell full of horrors.
Lies delirious in fever, showing physical and possibly mental decline, making no effort to protect himself from insects.
Attempts to protect important documents from rain despite his weakened state.
Hums a song while walking with his son, watches his son's playful antics with amusement, calls his son affectionately and lifts him onto the mule.
Encourages Diego to show affection to his brother Fernando.
Explains his decision to separate the brothers as being for Diego's best interest and praises Diego's teacher.
Explains his decision regarding Diego's education confidently and respectfully, showing thoughtful consideration for his brother's future.
Attempts to encourage Diego to show affection to Fernando, demonstrating social awareness and leadership within family dynamics.
Expresses excitement and disbelief upon receiving the letter about speaking at the University of Salamanca.
Engages in a detailed, patient explanation of his plan to sail west to open a new route to Asia.
Responds with excitement and urgency upon receiving the letter inviting him to speak at the University of Salamanca, showing awareness of opportunity and timing.
Asks Marchena how he managed to secure the invitation, demonstrating curiosity and recognition of the importance of support.
Explains his plan to open a new route to Asia by sailing west, using maps and logical reasoning to outline existing routes and their limitations.
Responds to Marchena's criticism with mockery and ignores his correction.
Defends the Jewish scholar Esdras by pointing out Christ was also Jewish.
Lifts Fernando onto the mule, showing care for his family.
Proposes a bold new route to the Indies by sailing west across the ocean, showing confidence in his calculations despite skepticism.
Relies on calculations from sources like Toscanelli and Marin de Tyr to support his theory, demonstrating use of knowledge and reasoning.
Dismisses Marchena's interruption about Esdras being a Jew with a witty retort, showing confidence but also a tendency to be dismissive rather than engaging fully.
Becomes mockingly defensive and admits passion is uncontrollable, indicating emotional impulsiveness that could undermine rational decision-making.
Invites Diego to come and stay with them, offers to do whatever makes him happy, touches his shoulder.
Tries to stop Fernando from running into the dangerous crowd but is unable to prevent it.
Takes Fernando's hand and drags him away from the execution scene to protect him from trauma.
Tousles Fernando's hair in a familiar, affectionate gesture.
Explains Fernando's subdued manner to Beatrix calmly and matter-of-factly.
Notices his son's distress and removes him from a traumatic scene, showing awareness and protective behavior.
Calmly explains the cause of his son's subdued behavior to his wife, demonstrating clear communication and emotional intelligence.
Mentions that 'They've agreed to see me in a week,' indicating he has arranged a meeting, showing planning and negotiation skills.
Kisses Beatrix tenderly before leaving, shares a moment of laughter and intimacy despite his absences.
Pours wine into Fernando's water to distract him and lighten the mood, then compliments Beatrix to Fernando with a wink.
Expresses doubt about living with a woman, showing vulnerability.
Pours wine into Fernando's water to distract him and lighten the mood, then engages him with a compliment about Beatrix, showing social tact and emotional intelligence.
Expresses doubts about his ability to live with a woman, showing some self-awareness but also possible emotional insecurity.
Engages warmly and playfully with Beatrix despite long absences, maintaining relationship bonds.
No clear demonstration of professional or intellectual competence in this excerpt; mostly personal and emotional interactions.
Responds respectfully and patiently to the skeptical questioning of the monk and other dignitaries, calmly presenting his knowledge and views.
Confidently asserts that Asia can be reached by sailing west in six or seven weeks, showing knowledge of geography and navigation.
Claims familiarity with the works of Aristotle, Erathostene, and Ptolemeus when challenged, demonstrating intellectual preparation.
Faces skepticism from learned men who cite established scientific calculations about Earth's circumference, indicating a potential underestimation of opposition or overconfidence.
Presses his controversial theories despite murmurs of protest, showing determination.
Acknowledges the concerns of Arojaz about the crew's safety with respect.
Presses his theories confidently despite opposition, citing respected authorities to support his claims.
Underestimates the length of the voyage and the practical difficulties such as water supply, leading to skepticism from others.
Acknowledges the concerns of others respectfully and concedes their point, showing awareness of risks.
Admits to being a simple man craving knowledge and acknowledges uncertainty among experts.
Passionately offers to risk his life to prove his theory and lead others.
Expresses intent to find new populations and bring them to the word of God.
Responds calmly and confidently to accusations of heresy, maintains unflinching eye contact with the monk.
Uses a religious metaphor to inspire and justify his mission, showing conviction.
Calmly defends his controversial belief that Asia can be found to the west and commits to proving it despite opposition.
Meets the monk's threatening gaze unflinchingly, showing confidence and composure under pressure.
Uses a religious analogy to justify his mission, demonstrating rhetorical skill and persuasive confidence.
Looks appalled and devastated upon reading the rejection letter; expresses frustration that they didn't listen or want to listen.
Looks appalled and devastated upon reading the rejection letter; paces about the room expressing frustration that they didn't listen.
Expresses intense frustration and anger by cursing God and others, violently throwing books, and knocking down Marchena.
Expresses intense frustration and impatience, lashes out violently by destroying books and knocking down Marchena.
Demonstrates passionate conviction and confidence in his beliefs, refusing to accept conventional wisdom.
Smiles politely at Pinzon but does not engage in conversation.
Cautiously moves away from others to speak privately with Pinzon, showing secretive behavior.
Pins up a new map carefully and maintains a vow of silence, showing discipline and strategic caution when approached by Pinzon.
Walks away from others to speak privately with Pinzon, indicating awareness of secrecy and control over information.
Does not immediately respond verbally to Pinzon's questions, which could be seen as overly secretive or uncommunicative.
Nods in agreement with Pinzon's offer of help and shows interest in meeting Santangel.
Looks around, catches the disapproving face of the Monk, crosses himself before speaking.
Nods in agreement to Pinzon's plan and shows willingness to collaborate despite initial hesitation.
Laughs and ducks behind a map when Pinzon speaks, showing a moment of informal confidence and ease in social interaction.
Looks increasingly interested and asks practical questions about meeting Santangel, demonstrating curiosity and proactive behavior.
Crosses himself and notices the disapproving monk before speaking, indicating awareness of social/religious pressures but still proceeding.
Observes the defeated Moors and the tragic aftermath of the siege silently, without showing empathy or offering aid.
Engages in polite conversation with Santangel and dignitaries, showing respect and patience.
Suggests meeting the Queen at a strategically advantageous moment, showing awareness of political timing.
Passively follows Santangel's lead in courtly interactions without asserting himself.
Falls to his knees before Queen Isabel, then boldly speaks with sincerity and challenges her views.
Engages in a respectful, somewhat playful exchange with Queen Isabel, showing openness and directness.
Boldly challenges Queen Isabel's doubts and council's verdict, showing confidence and persuasive skill.
Demonstrates awareness of political realities by recognizing Isabel's vulnerability and scrutinizing her, indicating strategic thinking.
Engages in light, playful banter with Isabel, showing familiarity and humor.
Compliments Isabel by calling her the only Queen he knows, showing respect and friendliness.
Comments on Isabel's age in a way that surprises and slightly flusters her, indicating a personal and sincere interaction.
Engages Isabel with confident, witty banter, showing social ease and quick thinking.
Turns back to make a playful, unexpected comment after leaving, leaving Isabel stunned.
Demands numerous high titles and a large share of wealth in his contract.
Proposes a contract demanding high titles, extensive privileges, and a large share of wealth from discoveries.
Demands appear excessive and provoke strong negative reactions from others, suggesting overreach or poor negotiation strategy.
Refuses to accept unfair contract terms, insists on fairness and equity.
Expresses frustration and anger but tries to remain calm.
Uses sarcasm and a mocking smile when challenged.
Firmly rejects an unfavorable contract, stands his ground against a powerful official, and confidently asserts his demands despite pressure.
Dismisses the official's authority and risks losing support by refusing to compromise, potentially jeopardizing his goals.
Turns and looks at Beatrix almost sad, shares a quiet moment with her.
Shouts unexpectedly in the street, drawing attention but then walks on expressionless.
Seems unable to share Beatrix's happiness fully despite her smile and gentle touch.
Strides out expressionless and distracted, then unexpectedly shouts loudly in public, causing people to think he is insane.
Sits alone quietly drinking wine, appears sad and unable to share happiness even after receiving a positive response (She said yes).
Gently kisses Beatrix despite telling her not to wait for him.
Reassures his son Fernando by transforming frightening monsters on the map into smiling figures, making him laugh.
Promises his son he will take him along one day and swears on all the saints, then hugs him tightly.
Calmly reassures his son by transforming frightening monsters on the map into friendly images, showing imaginative confidence and emotional intelligence.
Promises his son he will take him along on his journey, showing confidence and commitment.
Engages in a tender moment with Beatrix, showing emotional awareness but no direct indication of competence related to his goals or skills.
Admits to Father Marchena that he has lied about the journey's length and confesses his betrayal of family, men, and the priest.
Refuses to tell his men the truth about the longer journey out of fear they won't follow him.
Admits to Father Marchena that he lied about the journey length and that it will be longer than stated, showing awareness of the situation's gravity.
Chooses not to tell his men the truth about the longer journey, fearing they won't follow him, indicating a strategic but possibly manipulative decision.
Kisses and hugs his son Fernando, shows emotional connection and care.
Asks Fernando to be good to his mother, showing concern for family well-being.
Clumsily hugs Diego, unable to find words but still shows physical affection.
Hugs Santangel wordlessly, indicating a sincere and friendly bond.
Refuses to speak to men about his certitude, fearing loss of their trust and following.
Refuses to tell his men the truth fearing they won't follow him, showing awareness of leadership dynamics and maintaining control.
Seeks absolution from Father Marchena, demonstrating internal conflict but also a sense of responsibility and awareness of moral consequences.
Shows emotional strength by comforting family members and maintaining composure during departure.
Unable to find words to speak to Diego, indicating some social or emotional awkwardness in personal relationships.
Unties the chain around his neck and throws it to Diego, who looks elated.
Laughs with Santangel after admitting he doesn't know where he is going.
Throws the medallion to Diego, showing trust and symbolic leadership.
Admits openly to Santangel that he does not know where he is going.
Patiently explains the use of the quadrant to Mendez and encourages him to try despite his hesitation.
Responds softly and with a hopeful blessing ('may God be with us') to Mendez.
Maintains focus on navigation but invites Mendez to participate and learn.
Uses a quadrant skillfully at night to determine the ship's position, confidently instructing others and explaining the importance of precision.
Responds calmly and authoritatively to Mendez's doubts and the crew's concerns about navigation after losing sight of land.
Confidently states the plan to follow the twenty eighth parallel until land is reached.
Decides to follow the twenty eighth parallel until they reach land, showing confidence in his navigation plan.
Stands silently on the poop deck, scrutinizing the horizon, not engaging with sailors' banter or concerns.
Stands on the poop deck, scrutinizing the horizon, waiting for land to appear.
Remains silent and does not engage with the sailors' bitter conversation or disrespect.
Makes careful navigational calculations using primitive tools and keeps a detailed log-book.
Demonstrates focus and attention to detail by monitoring the hourglass and converting measurements into daily averages.
Calmly grants permission to Pinzon to board despite tension.
Calmly insists on maintaining hope among the men despite mutiny and hardship.
Dismisses Pinzon's anger and accusations without addressing his concerns openly.
Calmly manages a tense situation with mutinous crew, grants permission to Pinzon to board, maintains hope among men despite adversity.
Lies about distance traveled to keep morale up, potentially risking trust and honesty.
Encourages moving forward despite adversity, tries to maintain morale.
Dismisses Pinzon's concerns and blames him for talking too much.
Faces surly men calmly and challenges their mutiny.
Defends and elevates the ship's boy by praising him in front of others.
Encourages the men by acknowledging their fear and inspiring them to overcome it, offering a reward for sighting land first.
Calls the ship's boy to start the lookout first, giving him responsibility and trust.
Walks away abruptly to his cabin after a brief exchange with Pinzon, showing some distance and lack of further engagement.
Slaps a mosquito on his temple reflexively, then stares at the crushed insect's blood spot.
Kneels by Mendez, touches his shoulder gently, and murmurs his name with concern.
Watches the land appear with disbelief and tears in his eyes, sharing the emotional moment silently with the crew.
Reflexively wakes up and notices the mosquito bite, then slowly gets to his feet, showing alertness and physical responsiveness.
Stares intently into the darkness, desperate to see the land, demonstrating focus and determination.
Kneels by the injured Mendez and tries to rouse him, showing care and leadership under stress.
Strains his eyes to see land but cannot immediately, showing patience and persistence rather than frustration.
Watches the land appear with disbelief and tears, indicating emotional vulnerability but also the weight of achievement.
Moved to tears at the sight of the new land, shows emotional sincerity.
Claims the island formally and leads the men forward, inspiring awe and respect.
Leaps out of the boat and confidently leads the landing party onto the beach, carrying the banner of Castille and Aragon.
Signs the contract on the beach, fulfilling formalities of claiming the land.
Struggles emotionally and momentarily cannot continue his speech, needing external help to regain composure.
Raises hand to signal not to fire, drops sword, and walks forward to meet the Indians peacefully despite warnings.
Puts his arm around the ship's boy to show affection, which helps put the Indians at ease.
Slowly lifts his hand to signal not to fire, showing control and calm in a tense situation.
Drops his sword and walks forward alone into no-man's land despite warnings, demonstrating confidence and leadership.
Puts his arm around the ship's boy to ease tensions with the Indians, showing emotional intelligence and skillful diplomacy.
Ignores Pinzon's warning to be cautious, potentially risking safety.
Puts his arm around the boy, a gesture of affection that puts the Indians at ease.
Laughs with the Indians as they touch his beard, sharing a moment of mutual amusement.
Gestures to Spaniards to treat the Indians with respect, forbidding pillage and rape, emphasizing honor and peaceful behavior.
Puts his arm around the boy to put the Indians at ease, laughs with them as they touch his beard, helping to lower tensions and weapons.
Gives clear, firm orders to his men to treat the Indians with respect and punish pillage and rape harshly, demonstrating leadership and foresight.
Insists that Pinzon give the Indian the dagger in exchange for the gold ornament, overriding Pinzon's reluctance.
Insists Pinzon give the Indian a dagger to secure the gold ornament, showing decisiveness and confidence in negotiation.
Fails to foresee the danger of giving a dagger to the Indian, resulting in injury and tension.
Draws Utapan's face, shares the drawing, laughs with him, and puts a hand on his shoulder in a gesture of friendship.
Follows Utapan through the jungle and obeys his order to sit, showing respect and trust.
Skillfully sketches Utapan's face, creating a moment of connection and friendship.
Follows Utapan through the jungle and obeys his command to sit, showing adaptability and respect.
Interprets the pool of water turned golden by sunlight as a valuable discovery, demonstrating perceptiveness.
Observes the interaction between Utapan and the Indian elder, asks clarifying questions about the island.
Commands 'Help him!' when Alonso is bitten by a snake, showing concern for his companion's wellbeing.
Observes the interaction between Utapan and the Indian elder, asks clarifying questions about the meaning of 'Cuba' to understand the situation.
Commands to help Alonso after the snake bite, showing prompt response to an emergency.
Relies on Utapan's interpretation and does not take direct action or show deeper understanding of the terrain or risks, indicating some dependence on others.
Calls out to Utapan to wait and returns to check on the group.
Looks around at exhausted men and jungle, then decides to stop the expedition.
Doggedly keeps up with UTAPAN despite suffering from heat and insect bites.
Calls out to UTAPAN and waits for him to return, showing leadership and control.
Observes the exhausted men and jungle, then decides to stop the expedition.
Attempts to prevent the Indian shaman from forcing medicine on Pinzon but is stopped by Utapan and then trusts Utapan's judgment.
Shows excitement and appreciation for the gold gift from Chief Guarionex and waits respectfully for the chief to speak.
Attempts to prevent the Indian shaman from forcing a milky fluid into Pinzon's mouth, showing concern and some assertiveness.
Trusts Utapan's judgment about the shaman's healing, demonstrating reliance on local knowledge and diplomacy.
Receives the gold mask with excitement, showing recognition of the importance of the find.
Waits silently for Chief Guarionex to speak after receiving the gift, showing patience and respect.
Thanks the Chief and compliments his country as very beautiful.
Attempts to explain the purpose of leaving men to build a fort and to bring the word of God and medicine, showing some respect and admiration for the Chief's people.
Interrupts Utapan to insist the Chief has medicine, showing impatience and lack of tolerance.
Smiles slightly and says 'That's a beginning' after the Chief smiles and awards him, indicating a friendly and hopeful attitude.
Attempts to communicate diplomatically with the Chief through a translator, expressing gratitude and intentions to build a fort and return with many men.
Fails to understand the Chief's simple question about why thousands of men would come, showing a momentary lapse in comprehension.
Quickly recovers from confusion and tries to explain the purpose of bringing God and medicine, showing adaptability in communication.
Interrupts the translator to correct or clarify the Chief's statement about medicine, indicating impatience or poor listening.
Maintains a positive attitude at the end, smiling and calling the interaction 'a beginning,' showing confidence and optimism.
Encourages crew to get below deck during violent storm, showing concern for their safety.
Commands Mendez to stay with him during the storm, indicating a desire for companionship and mutual support.
Writes detailed log entries despite difficult conditions, showing persistence and reflection.
Commands sailors to get below deck during violent storm, demonstrating leadership and quick decision-making.
Crawls towards the mast with Mendez during the storm, showing physical courage and presence of mind.
Commands Mendez to stay with him and helps tie himself to the mast to face the storm together.
Screams at Mendez to go below deck despite Mendez's hesitation, showing impatience.
Laughs after counting the thunderclaps, showing resilience and shared experience in the storm.
Decides to stay tied to the mast to make a critical decision about cutting it, showing leadership and presence of mind during a violent storm.
Commands Mendez firmly to go below deck despite Mendez's hesitation, demonstrating decisiveness and authority.
Counts the thunderclaps to gauge the storm's progress, showing situational awareness and calm under pressure.
Screams 'Damn you!' at the storm, showing emotional reaction but quickly regains composure and continues counting.
Is amazed and distracted by a mysterious projectile moving through the air during the storm.
Walks proudly down the aisle beside the King and Queen, keeping his eyes on Beatrix until she is out of his vision.
Walks proudly in a grand procession with King Ferdinand and Queen Isabel, receiving public honor and recognition for his achievements.
Maintains confident composure and focus on family member Beatrix despite the grandeur and attention around him.
Sits on a stool placed at the Queen and King's side, a supreme privilege indicating his elevated status and acceptance by the court.
Takes cigar from Moxica, demonstrates how to enjoy tobacco without inhaling, sharing cultural knowledge in a friendly manner.
Describes the native people as living in harmony with nature, without sin, in a poetic and gentle way, causing Isabel to blush slightly.
Demonstrates confident knowledge about tobacco use and instructs others on how to enjoy it properly.
Describes the native people and their lifestyle with vivid detail, showing cultural understanding and persuasive storytelling.
Responds to Sanchez's question about gold by discreetly signaling a servant to bring a casket, indicating preparedness and strategic presentation.
Presents gifts to the Queen with respectful words.
Bows slightly to the Queen and guests, showing politeness.
Engages in friendly banter with Sanchez, sharing a drink and exchanging compliments.
Makes a slightly sarcastic remark to Sanchez calling him a 'commoner'.
Presents gifts of gold to the Queen, successfully impressing the court and eliciting a positive reaction.
Engages in skilled fencing practice, demonstrating physical capability and discipline.
Exchanges confident, witty banter with Sanchez, showing social confidence and composure.
Politely informs Don Bobadilla that governor positions are already taken by his sons.
Jokes that there are no thieves so no need for judges, causing a grimace on Bobadilla's face.
Engages in a somewhat sarcastic exchange with Bobadilla, showing little effort to ease tensions or build friendship.
Confidently asserts that the governor positions have already been taken by his relatives, showing control over appointments.
Attempts to downplay the need for Bobadilla's services by claiming there are no thieves and that judges are not needed, which causes visible displeasure.
Fails to recognize or manage the social tension and displeasure his statements cause, leading to Bobadilla walking off annoyed.
Expresses pained surprise when brothers hesitate to help, tries to include them as trusted family.
Nods and murmurs vaguely to applicants, giving polite but non-committal responses.
Puts arms around brothers, appeals to family loyalty and trust.
Calmly manages tension with his brothers, appeals to family loyalty and trust to secure their support for the expedition.
Engages with a large crowd of applicants, acknowledges them politely but vaguely without concrete commitments.
Shows pained surprise at brothers' reluctance, indicating some emotional vulnerability in leadership moments.
Engages with the crowd, jokes about the royal surgeon, causing laughter.
Shows affection to Beatrix by putting his arm around her waist and pulling her closer.
Offers to arrange for his sons to enter the Queen's service, presenting it as a great honor.
Responds promptly to the soldier's call and inquires about the hired personnel, showing awareness and engagement.
Acknowledges the arrival of the royal surgeon and makes a confident, optimistic remark about health support, demonstrating leadership and morale boosting.
Engages in a personal conversation with Beatrix about arranging royal service for his sons, showing foresight and strategic thinking about his family's future.
Fails to notice Beatrix's unease about his plan, missing an emotional cue that might affect family dynamics.
Puts his arm around Beatrix's waist, pulling her closer as they move away.
Stares into the jungle in dismay at the destruction and absence of his men.
Stands calmly with his men, observing the jungle and awaiting a signal, showing patience and leadership.
Looks around in dismay at the burned camp and ominous signs, indicating a moment of uncertainty or lack of preparedness.
Refuses to allow revenge killings despite pressure, urges restraint and focus on building a future.
Acknowledges his own loss and grief openly to others.
Uses a firm tone to command obedience to prevent violence.
Calms his men and forbids revenge despite pressure, showing leadership and strategic thinking to avoid unnecessary conflict.
Acknowledges the loss of his men and appeals to reason and long-term goals rather than immediate retaliation.
Demonstrates awareness of the dangers of the environment and the numerical disadvantage, advising caution and focus on survival and mission.
Stops his soldiers from attacking the natives despite their eagerness for violence, insists on peace and cooperation.
Calmly defuses a tense situation by ordering restraint and proposing peace despite having military advantage.
Relies on a translator (Utapan) to communicate important decisions, showing awareness of language barriers and cultural mediation.
Shouts encouragement to the mixed workforce despite difficult conditions.
Insists that Don Moxica contribute his horse, physically grabbing the reins to assert his request.
Thanks Don Moxica sincerely after he complies, acknowledging his effort publicly.
Insists on using Don Moxica's horse despite initial refusal, demonstrating persistence and leadership to solve the problem of raising the heavy watermill wheel.
Supervises the construction of the watermill and dam in difficult conditions, encouraging the workforce despite challenges.
Encourages Giacomo to eat the unfamiliar food and tries to lighten the mood with humor.
Dismisses Giacomo's discomfort with the food by emphasizing Indian customs without much empathy.
Encourages his brother to adapt to local conditions by eating iguana, showing practical acceptance of new environment.
Dismisses his brother's discomfort with unfamiliar food somewhat bluntly, showing limited sensitivity but practical focus.
Smiles with his brothers at their younger brother's exhaustion, sharing a light moment.
Jokes about being 'Governor of the Mosquitoes' after killing a mosquito, showing a sense of humor.
Expresses doubt about the existence of gold, showing some vulnerability and openness.
Questions the lack of gold found and reflects on the possibility that it may only exist in his imagination, showing awareness of the situation's reality.
Jokes about being 'Governor of the Mosquitoes' after acknowledging failure to find gold, indicating a lighthearted or possibly resigned attitude rather than decisive action.
No direct action or statement present in the excerpt.
Condemns Moxica's brutal act and expresses concern about its consequences on relations with the Indians.
Presides over a tribunal to hold Moxica accountable for his cruelty.
Presides over a tribunal, calmly reprimands Moxica for his brutality, and recognizes the political consequences of the violence.
Allows Moxica's violent actions to occur initially without intervention, indicating a lack of control over his subordinates.
Urges Utapan to find the culprits of the crucifixions, showing a desire to stop the violence.
Is silent with rage at the crucifixions, indicating emotional response but no immediate conciliatory action.
Acknowledges the need to stop the war after Utapan points out hypocrisy, showing some openness and sincerity.
Silently shows rage at the crucifixion of Spaniards, then calmly instructs Utapan to find the perpetrators despite the moral conflict.
Acknowledges the need to stop the war after being challenged by Utapan, showing some flexibility and awareness.
Is caught short and momentarily speechless when Utapan points out hypocrisy, indicating a momentary lapse in confidence or preparedness.
Shouts 'Stop! Stop this!' to halt indiscriminate shooting.
Stands silently looking at the burning remains of the mansion, showing disbelief.
Leads his soldiers through dangerous jungle terrain despite risks to men.
Kills a mutineer who lunges at him during battle.
Leads men into dangerous combat, continuing to advance despite losses.
Leads men across a dangerous river under fire, engages in hand-to-hand combat, kills a mutineer attacking him, and pursues the enemy up a difficult cliff despite exhaustion.
Continues forward confidently even as his men are outnumbered and some begin to surrender.
Gives a signal to execute a mutineer, remains expressionless during the execution.
Stares at captured Indians packed in cages with vacant eyes, shows no visible empathy.
Responds to Brother Buyl's wish to leave with a cold, dismissive remark.
Orders the execution of mutineers decisively, maintaining control over the rebellion.
Sits expressionless and detached during executions, showing emotional control and command presence.
Allows Brother Buyl to leave despite his disapproval, showing pragmatic leadership and confidence in his decisions.
Shows indifference or coldness toward the suffering of captured Indians, indicating a lack of empathy or moral consideration.
Speaks quietly about hope and dreams, showing vulnerability and introspection.
Sits alone all night on the balcony, seemingly isolated and reflective.
Attempts to communicate with Utapan, asking him to speak and recalling past connection.
Fails to learn Utapan's language, leading to a communication barrier and emotional distance.
Quietly offers a new world as a reward after executing nobility, showing confidence in his vision despite opposition.
Sits silently all night on the balcony, reflecting and speaking almost to himself, indicating introspection but also possible isolation or indecision.
Fails to communicate effectively with Utapan, who states Columbus never learned his language, highlighting a lack of cultural understanding and communication skills.
Struggles alongside men to save the dam during the hurricane.
Screams to men to let the dam go to avoid danger.
Attempts to physically save the dam during the hurricane, showing direct involvement and leadership in a crisis.
Recognizes the futility of saving the dam and orders to let it go, demonstrating situational awareness and decisiveness under pressure.
After the disaster, is found lying on his bed in a devastated state, covered in dried mud, possibly indicating exhaustion or defeat.
Fails to find promised gold and subjects natives to violence and injustice, leading to calls for his replacement.
Congratulates Bobadilla on his appointment sincerely despite personal setback.
Responds calmly and without bitterness to Bobadilla's mocking remarks.
Responds calmly to Bobadilla's announcement of his appointment and the discovery of the mainland by another, showing measured acceptance and focus on his own goals.
Asks practical questions about the distance to the mainland, demonstrating presence of mind and strategic thinking despite bad news.
Pales visibly upon hearing the news, showing emotional impact but quickly recovers to maintain composure.
Is imprisoned and appears physically and mentally deteriorated, indicating loss of control and failure to maintain his position.
Laughs, overcome with joy, embraces Diego and Fernando upon their arrival.
Expresses excitement about exploring the mainland and includes Fernando in his plans.
Hugs Diego and sincerely says he is happy for him despite Diego feeling like an outsider.
Despite his poor physical condition and imprisonment, he remains focused on his goals, immediately expressing a desire to return and explore the mainland, showing determination and confidence.
Laughs and shows joy upon seeing his sons, indicating emotional resilience and ability to maintain morale under hardship.
Ignores the practical concerns of his sons about his health and current state, insisting on going back to explore, which may indicate recklessness or poor judgment.
Drops to his knees before Queen Isabel, showing humility and respect.
Maintains clear, sincere eye contact with Isabel despite physical deterioration.
Attempts to interrupt Isabel when she announces conditions, showing impatience.
Shows humility and penitence by kneeling before Queen Isabel, demonstrating respect and awareness of his past faults.
Maintains clear, confident eye contact with Isabel despite physical deterioration, showing mental sharpness and confidence.
Attempts to interrupt Isabel when she announces conditions, indicating possible impatience or lack of full control in the situation.
Thanks Isabel politely after being granted permission for another voyage.
Explains sincerely and openly his personal motivation to see the new world with his own eyes.
Seizes Sanchez by the arm and challenges him to call the guards, showing boldness but also a confrontational attitude.
Lets go of Sanchez without escalating the conflict after the challenge.
Engages Sanchez in a somewhat philosophical conversation about creation and legacy, showing a desire for mutual understanding.
Politely accepts the Queen's conditions without argument.
Expresses a strong personal conviction and motivation to see the new world firsthand.
Confronts Sanchez boldly and physically seizes him, showing confidence and assertiveness.
Challenges Sanchez to call the guards, demonstrating fearlessness and control of the situation.
Engages Sanchez in a psychological exchange, using observation and rhetoric to assert superiority.
Expresses deep affection and longing for Beatrix, calling her beautiful and showing emotional vulnerability.
Laughs and shares a warm, intimate moment with Beatrix despite their loss, showing sincerity and good-naturedness.
Embraces Santangel like an old friend, indicating friendliness and trustworthiness.
Turns abruptly and walks away after a confrontation, avoiding engagement.
Turns abruptly and walks away after being contradicted.
Returns to his manor house and calmly surveys the emptiness and loss without panic.
Expresses emotional vulnerability and focuses on personal freedom rather than material wealth.
Maintains warm, confident social interactions with Beatrix and Santangel despite difficult circumstances.
Embraces Santangel like an old friend and expresses gratitude sincerely.
Smiles and shares a light moment with Santangel and Beatrix, laughing and drinking together.
Leans next to his seasick son Fernando, showing quiet concern and understanding without pressuring him.
Acknowledges his limitations as a politician but embraces his role as a sailor and discoverer with imagination.
Shows emotional intelligence by sharing a moment of camaraderie and humor with Santangel despite difficulties.
Observes his son Fernando's seasickness and understands his struggle, showing awareness and empathy.
Asks his sick son how he is feeling, shares a home remedy, smiles and pats him on the back after he vomits.
Discreetly watches his sons excitement upon sighting land, enjoying his happiness.
Directs ship operations despite having an obvious fever.
Offers an old folk remedy (pork fat on a string) to his sick son, which causes the son to vomit.
Calmly observes and enjoys his son's happiness upon sighting land, showing emotional control and confidence.
Watches the Old Indian with initial puzzlement, then growing excitement; listens carefully to the Indian's drawing and explanation.
Asks the translator to clarify the Old Indian's meaning, showing openness and respect for the native's knowledge.
Takes charcoal and draws on the map for his son, sharing the discovery in a personal and inclusive way.
Observes the old Indian's drawing carefully, tries to understand the new information, and asks clarifying questions through the translator.
Initially puzzled and stunned by the new information about the isthmus and ocean, showing momentary confusion.
Responds to surprising information by incorporating it into his map and explaining it to his son, demonstrating adaptability and communication.
Allows the translator (an Indian) to help him by administering a traditional remedy despite initial reluctance from his son.
His son Fernando anxiously watches over him and bathes his eyes while he is ill.
Explains the discovery of a new continent confidently to his son, showing understanding of geography and significance.
Falls ill with a fever and requires help from others, showing physical vulnerability but accepts assistance.
Recovers from fever and confidently observes the mainland, smiling at the achievement.
Stares at the remains of human flesh, stunned and concerned.
Urgently orders the Spaniards to get out of the village to avoid danger.
Stares at the remains, stunned, showing initial shock but quickly reacts by ordering the men to get out urgently.
Jumps to defend Fernando from a charging cannibal, showing protective instinct.
Stabs the cannibal repeatedly in a frenzied, furious manner, then is shocked by his own fury.
Sits near his son Fernando, kindly offers him a flask of alcohol to calm him.
Jumps on a charging enemy and kills him with multiple stabs, showing physical courage and decisiveness in combat.
Stops abruptly after killing the enemy, shocked by his own fury and distracted by a butterfly, momentarily losing focus during a dangerous situation.
Responds to his son's urgent call and runs with the group to escape, demonstrating situational awareness and ability to retreat under pressure.
Sits calmly beside his traumatized son and kindly encourages him to drink alcohol to calm down, showing emotional intelligence and care.
Expresses deep remorse and self-blame for involving his brother, asks for forgiveness.
Allows Fernando to care for him while he is ill, showing vulnerability and trust.
Dictates a sincere letter emphasizing honest purpose and zeal, denying selfish motives.
Hides his injured hand and stands despite obvious physical distress, showing determination to continue.
Expresses regret and self-blame for taking his son along, indicating emotional vulnerability but also self-awareness.
Dictates a clear, reasoned letter to the monarch explaining his discoveries and intentions, demonstrating articulate communication and strategic thinking.
Appears physically debilitated by fever and pain, requiring assistance and unable to act independently.
Writes a humble letter asking to be remembered with honor and appealing to charity, truth, and justice.
Listens impassively to public recognition of his discovery without visible emotional response.
Writes a letter presenting himself as a seaman who discovered a New World by Divine Will and requests that his name be remembered with honor.
Listens impassively to a public lecture confirming the discovery of a new continent he made, showing calm confidence.
Shares a warm, sincere moment with Antonio de Marchena, laughs and asks if forgiven.
Stands unnoticed and isolated in the crowd, not engaging with others.
Appears unnoticed and isolated in a crowd, suggesting diminished presence or influence.
Engages in a quiet, personal moment with Marchena, showing self-awareness and capacity for reconciliation.
Engages in a friendly, thoughtful conversation with Marchena, sharing his views sincerely and laughing together.
Holds Beatrix back gently, asking her to stay a little longer, then smiles at her.
Accepts disagreement from Marchena but maintains a warm, respectful tone.
Insists on discovering things for himself despite risks and hurting others, showing persistence and independent thinking.
Expresses disagreement with a resigned worldview and asserts belief in change and new possibilities.
Admits he hasn't changed much and still struggles to accept the world as it is, showing self-awareness but also possible stubbornness.
Attempts to engage Beatrix to stay with him despite her refusal, showing a gentle but somewhat ineffective social approach.
Expresses affectionate interest in Beatrix, wanting to catch up on lost moments.
Smiles and shows joy when hearing from Mendez, sharing a lighthearted comment.
Appears somewhat detached or indifferent about the restoration of privileges and house, focusing instead on family well-being.
Smiles and nods, showing little concern for the restoration of privileges and house, indicating detachment from practical matters.
Engages warmly and humorously with Fernando and Beatrix, showing social ease but no clear demonstration of skill or intelligence.
Appears unable to clearly recall or organize his memories when asked to recount events, indicating possible difficulty in reflection or communication.
